statement.tex: \text{Sand is pouring from a pipe at the rate}\\ \text{of 12 cm$^3$/s. The falling sand forms a cone}\\ \text{on the ground in such a way that the height of}\\ \text{the cone is always one-sixth of the radius}\\ \text{of the base. How fast is the height of the sand}\\ \text{cone increasing when the height is 4 cm?}
\\ \text{What do we know and }\\ \text{what do we have to find?}

options.tex: \text{We know}\\ \quad R=6\cdot H\text{ and }V = 12\text{ cm$^3$}\\ \text{And we have to find} \quad\left[\frac{dH}{dT}\right]

reason.tex: \text{Both }\frac{dV}{dT}\text{ and }\frac{R}{H}\text{ are known. They are}\\ \text{also constant. What we need to find is }\frac{dH}{dT}.
\text{The volume of a cone is } V=\frac{1}{3}\pi R^2 H. \\ \text{And, }\frac{dV}{dT} = \frac{dV}{dH}\times\frac{dH}{dT}.
\text{Check the calculations if you got them wrong.}
